title: Waterstones Boss Talks About AI Books
summary: The boss of Waterstones, a big bookstore chain, said they might sell books made by artificial intelligence (AI) if customers want them and if the books are clearly labeled as AI-created. However, he personally doesn't think this will happen soon because most AI-generated content isn't good enough to sell. AI is a computer technology that can create things like stories, and it's causing a lot of talk in the book world. Writers are worried that AI could take their jobs, but some writers use AI to help with research or editing. Waterstones uses AI for logistics, like making sure books arrive on time, but they try to keep AI books out of stores for now. The boss believes in letting store managers decide what books to feature based on their local communities. He also mentioned that many authors fear being replaced by AI, and some of their work has been used without permission to train AI tools.

background_read: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that lets computers do tasks that usually need human thinking, like writing stories or solving problems. In the book industry, AI can help create books, but it also raises concerns about job loss for authors. Waterstones is a popular bookstore chain in the UK known for selling many types of books. Store managers are important because they choose books that fit their local customers' interests. Logistics involves planning how to move books from publishers to stores efficiently. Authors write books and often worry about new technologies affecting their work.
Article_Structure: WHO: James Daunt, the boss of Waterstones, and authors in the publishing industry.
WHAT: Waterstones might sell AI-generated books if labeled and wanted by customers, but the boss doubts it will happen soon.
WHERE: In Waterstones bookstores across the UK.
WHY: To discuss the impact of AI on bookselling and authors' concerns about job replacement.

perspectives.description: Waterstones is open to selling AI books if customers want them, but prefers human-created books and gives store managers control.
Authors are worried AI could replace them and that their work is used without permission to train AI tools.
